The second had to start over because my current work disappeared.

The third didn't worry about money or time, and just followed pure curiosity.

This is one of four simple exercises from Stanford's Life Design Lab.

When I did this exercise, future self three was building stuff, exploring and working with kids.
¬†
This also made me realize that I can bring more creativity into my life, like using illustrations or adding music to my work presentations üòâ
¬†
What would your three life plans look like?
¬†
Which one scares you the most?
¬†
Which one excites you the most?
¬†
And what can we bring from these futures to our day-to-day?

data.text:
Google rewards effort, not just outcomes. 

At first, this seemed backwards to me. 

Shouldn't results matter most?

But when we only reward success, we stop taking risks. 

We choose the safe project over the breakthrough idea. 

I've seen this happen many times, "playing it safe" instead of risking exposure to criticism.

And I also caught myself as part of the problem, worrying too much on "covering my a**" instead of doing my absolute best.

Now I try to ask myself: am I celebrating the person who tried something new and failed, or just the one who hit their predictable targets?

At the same time, how do you encourage risk-taking without losing accountability?

data.text:
What's under your emotional rug?

Our upbringing deeply influences which emotional expressions feel "allowed" and which ones we automatically convert into more acceptable alternatives.

Some people express anger when they should cry, while others cry when they should express anger, all based on childhood lessons about acceptable emotional displays.

Understanding which emotions were welcomed versus discouraged in your childhood reveals the key to your current emotional patterns and limitations.

As parents today, we have the responsibility to break these limiting patterns by showing our children the full range of healthy emotional expression: fathers who cry, mothers who express anger

In this way we free them from the stereotypes that may have restricted our own emotional development.

A clip from my conversation with the inspiring Lousin Mehrabi.

data.text:
A few months ago, I watched a podcast interview with a writer whose book changed how I think.

My immediate thought: "Why didn't I reach out to them first?"

Then my brain said: "Great, now there's no point. They're probably booked solid and wouldn't want to talk to me anyway."

This is the lie comparison tells us: 

That opportunities have expiration dates. 

Someone else's conversation means there's no room for mine.

But I realized that their interview didn't close a door. 

It opened one. 

It showed me exactly what kind of conversations I want to have 

And reminded me that I have something to say too.

Maybe I won't get that specific conversation. But I can create my own.

Are you letting someone else's move stop you from making yours?

data.text:
Most people prepare answers for meetings. 

The smartest people I know prepare questions instead.

The best conversations I've had happened when I asked better questions.

Not small talk like "How's business?" 

Instead, questions that showed I'd done my homework and cared about them.

Here's what I've learned works:

Preparation. 

You show respect when you take the time to prepare and research.

An example: when meeting someone for the first time, I check what they posted in the last two months.

Curiosity. 

One of my favorite questions is "what are you most excited about?"

You always find something interesting in everyone, if you look for it.

Challenge, with a smile. 

You help someone see their problem from a new angle. 

How I do it: I ask "may I challenge you a bit?" Rarely someone says no.

What's the best question someone's asked you recently?

data.text:
Google has killed 296 products. They call it "Google Graveyard".

Yet, gmail is still here, and I use it daily.

That's how innovation works: most experiments don't work out, and that's fine.

The companies that innovate aren't the ones afraid to try stuff. 

They're the ones comfortable with most of their bets not paying off.

So, your side project might flop. 

Your new approach might not work. 

Your idea might be terrible.

What is the alternative?

Never trying anything.

This guarantees you'll never find what works.

Just start your own experiments, and have fun if you can.

I read 44 books last year and probably learned more than I did in four years of college.

Not because I'm particularly smart, but because I forgot almost everything I learned in college üòÖ 

Well, while some of that is true, the main reason is that every book is someone's years of work distilled into a few hours of reading.

An entrepreneur spent a decade building a company, then wrote about what worked. 

A researcher spent 20 years studying habits, then shared the patterns.

A therapist saw thousands of patients, then explained what actually helps.

Reading isn't about collecting books. 

It's about borrowing other people's expensive lessons without paying their price.

And of course, there are books that we read and re-read, and every time we see something different, since we also change in the process.

Like for me "The almanack of Naval Ravikant" and "Hostage at the Table"

Other people's 'emergency' isn't your emergency.

Early in my career I was jumping every time someone said 'urgent'.

I was busy as hell but the meaningful stuff waited until evenings or weekends.

Before jumping into "emergency mode" you can ask: 'Will this matter in a week?'

Most 'urgent' stuff won't. 

It's usually just other people's poor planning.

What actually matters? 

Learning new skills, building relationships, working on projects you care about.

This rarely feels urgent.

It sits there while you're putting out fires.

Will you pause next time you hear 'urgent", and ask yourself if it's actually important or just loud?

Is AI depriving us of the learning journey? 

The day I discovered I could use ChatGPT to program with Python, I could not sleep.

I could finally do something that I had always wanted to do.

And I never had the time before because it was such a time investment.

Since then, I have written thousands of lines of code.

So many little apps that help me in my day-to-day automation.

üòà But is there a dark side to that? 

Does using AI make our brain and learning muscles atrophy?

This is what Dustin Curtis shares in a recent blog post

‚ÄúBut now, when my brain spontaneously forms a tiny sliver of a potentially interesting concept or idea, I can just shove a few sloppy words into a prompt and almost instantly get a fully reasoned, researched, and completed thought.‚Äù

‚ö†Ô∏è I can see the danger..

I can also think of how using Google Maps has made me forget how to navigate without it.

But can we avoid that?

To me, it (still) feels that what we get is more than what we lose in the process.

What are your thoughts?

data.text:
How micromanagement can suffocate creativity: it's not about font size. üòÖ

What is micromanagement? Chieh Huang defines it as the following: 

Micromanagement is taking great, wonderful, imaginative people, bringing them into an organization, and then crushing their souls by telling them what font size to use.üòì

The feeling of not having control over our jobs can bring us much more fatigue than the work itself.

So, what is the source of micromanagement? üîç

We start at the very bottom when we get hired. Doing work. 

And if we're really good at doing the work, the reward is more work. 

We do more work, and if we're really good at it, we start managing people doing it. 

And at that moment, we start to lose control over the output of our job. And we may overreact by micromanaging.

Chieh argues that there is only one solution to micromanagement: trusting your employees to fulfill their roles.ü§ù

Illustration by me üòä

data.text:
The secret to continuous growth? Engage in a community of practice.¬†üå± ü§ù

A community of practice (CoP) is a group of people with a shared concern, interest, or passion who deepen their knowledge and expertise in this area by interacting on an ongoing basis.

This is the definition from E. Wenger, R. McDermott, W. Snyder, and it has three main characteristics:

üåü A domain of knowledge: this shared purpose provides a unifying focus and helps define the boundaries of each community.

üåü A community of people: members contribute by sharing knowledge, insights, and resources, participating in discussions, asking questions, and seeking advice. 

üåü A shared set of tools and practices: while there are regular interactions among members, deciding how and how often they meet is up to them.

Why is a community of practice vital for us? üîç

CoPs can provide personal and professional development opportunities, inspiration, and emotional well-being. 

No matter how experienced we are, we must continue to learn and develop our mindsets, skillsets, and behaviors. 

Being part of any community is an opportunity to build connections outside our immediate circle and to expose us to different realities and ways of thinking.

üîÑ We will likely inspire and support someone else‚Äôs learning, too! As a result, community members grow together. 

Illustration by me üòä 

Excerpt from an article by Sara Ramos on the Management 3.0 blog.

data.text:
Choose life by design over the default work mode ‚ù§Ô∏è
¬†
"Our "default setting" may be just to work. Put our heads down, grind, and go home to recharge for another work day.
¬†
The concerning aspect is that we might unknowingly choose this life, never considering if it's time to opt out.
¬†
Perhaps it's worth questioning the "default setting" and living by design rather than by default.
¬†
I love the reflection from Sahil Bloom on this topic. He sees two core ideas:
¬†
‚ú® Being present and spending time with those you love is ultimately the most important thing.
¬†
‚ú® If the people we love see us working hard on things we care about, they will remember this principle for the rest of their lives.
¬†
We ultimately "win" the game by understanding, navigating, and balancing the tension across these two. ‚öñÔ∏è
¬†
The goal is not to sacrifice our career progression, learning, and potential but to be constantly present with our kids.
¬†
The goal is to have clarity in choosing, to define our balance, and to live by design rather than by default.
¬†
‚ùì A few questions that may help us think
¬†
What do our loved ones know about our work?¬†
¬†
Do they understand why we're working hard on it?¬†
¬†
What lights us up about it, and how can we include them?
¬†
I try to live by this, too. For example, as I wrote this, my kids were waiting to go and see a dinosaur exhibit. ü¶ï
¬†
I was planning to stay home to write more, so my son Luca came in here and asked me if I could go with them.
¬†
So I said "yes" and switched one activity in the afternoon for the morning, and told them that I'll be with them in the evening again üòä
¬†
Ultimately, we will never know if we made the "right" choice, as perfection does not exist. Still, we can do our best to show up daily and simultaneously invest in ourselves."
¬†

Among many of the ideas it expresses, two concepts especially caught my attention as a man, professional, and father of Valentina and Luca.

üöß The first is how important it is to overcome stereotypical behaviours and beliefs, specifically the traditional definition of masculinity.

"Demasculinizing" the world has positive consequences for everyone, including men.

For example, being able to live an emotionally peaceful and sustainable life or to experience fatherhood in a heartfelt, authentic, and profound way.

üåü One of the keys to accelerating change is for well-known and recognized males who act as role models to other men.

He cites the example of Justin Baldoni, a Hollywood actor whose Ted Talk titled "Why I'm Not Trying to Be Man Enough Anymore" has over eight million plays.

Justin's father passed on to him traditionally masculine skills while teaching him how to live his more emotional side.

This "balancing" between feminine and masculine values or traits is the second concept I loved.

‚û°Ô∏è Ideation and creativity. More feminine to let our imagination run wild and dream and then land the idea with that results orientation that comes from the masculine. 

‚û°Ô∏è Market research. Rationality and analytics (masculine) and observation and empathy to read the market (feminine). 

‚û°Ô∏è Business plan. More rationality than emotionality. Masculine.

‚û°Ô∏è Seeking and negotiating with investors. Confidence, decisiveness, ability to take risks, and communication skills. Masculine.

‚û°Ô∏è Hiring talent and creating a workplace. Intuition, patience, attention to detail, and neutrality. Feminine. 

‚û°Ô∏è Establishing company culture. Culture and values require sensitivity and observation skills. Feminine. 

‚û°Ô∏è Set team goals and measure performance. Challenge and discipline are critical at this stage. Masculine. 

‚û°Ô∏è Negotiating with customers, partners or suppliers. Assertiveness, building trust, assertiveness, analytical skills, empathy. We get the best results with balance.

‚û°Ô∏è Relationship management. Taking care of and maintaining the company's essential relationships, weaving a relational network. Feminine.

Being a father made me a better negotiator üòâ

Dad, buy me another lego!

Dad, I want to play maths!

Dad, I want to play cards!

Dad, I want more strawberries!

Dad, I don't want to go to school!

Dad, I don't want to put on my shoes!

Dad, I don't want to do the homework now!

These are daily "negotiation starters" with both my daughter and, especially, my son. And soon, as they become adolescents, the stakes will go up.

A strategy that has lately been working with my son Luca is making a "contract" with all the steps of the things we are going to do.

I make a concession.

He makes a concession.

We write it on a tablet.

Then we both sign it. Most of the time, it works!

data.text:
Reliability is a foundational quality that sets the best team players apart. ü§ù

Andre Durand said, ‚ÄúIf you look at the essence of trust, it‚Äôs a one-to-one ratio between say and do.‚Äù

Individuals who clearly express this issue demonstrate to the company that following through is essential. üîÑ

Some people, if they say they are going to do something, are like ‚Äúmoney in the bank.‚Äù We don‚Äôt have to think about that anymore.

With other people, we know we have to keep their to-do lists on our to-do list. If this is how most people in an organization operate, the business will be slower.

Reliability also goes to the heart of what it means to be a team player. It removes the hierarchy and acknowledges that everyone relies on one another to achieve a goal.

Paula Long captures the spirit of this idea. ‚ÄúI like to say that we‚Äôre all subcontractors to one another. It‚Äôs about accountability and respecting each other‚Äôs time.‚Äù

I would build on that and add three ideas:

‚úÖ Treating each colleague as an ‚Äúinternal customer‚Äù and thinking as if they will have to answer the question ‚ÄúHow likely are you to recommend me to others?‚Äù

‚úÖ Over-communicating and following up proactively, especially when we are struggling and in danger of not meeting a goal. It helps to build trust and transparency.

‚úÖ Whenever possible, overdeliver, even a tiny detail like extra thorough documentation or a 1:1 short call to anticipate the results. And in doubt, underpromise (but not too much)

data.text:
Adapting leadership in real-time: why mastering multiple styles is critical. üìò

There are six basic leadership styles, according to Daniel Goleman.

‚û°Ô∏è The coercive style

This approach can be convenient in a turnaround situation, but in most cases, it inhibits the organization‚Äôs flexibility and employees‚Äô motivation.

‚û°Ô∏è The pacesetting style. 

A leader who sets high standards and exemplifies them himself has a positive impact on employees who are self-motivated and highly competent. But other employees may feel overwhelmed.

‚û°Ô∏è The authoritative style. 

A ‚Äúcome with me‚Äù approach states the goal and allows people to choose how to achieve it. It is less effective when the team is more experienced than the leader.

‚û°Ô∏è The affiliative style. 

A ‚ÄúPeople come first‚Äù attitude. This style is beneficial for building team harmony but can allow poor performance to go uncorrected or omit crucial advice.

‚û°Ô∏è The democratic style. 

By giving workers a voice in decisions, democratic leaders build flexibility and responsibility and help generate ideas. But sometimes the price is endless meetings and confused employees.

‚û°Ô∏è The coaching style. 

Focused more on personal development than on immediate work-related tasks. It works well with self-aware employees who want to improve but not when they are resisting.

The more styles a leader masters, the better. Specifically, switching among authoritative, affiliative, democratic, and coaching styles as conditions dictate is very effective. ‚öôÔ∏è

data.text:
Hippo leadership: know when to surface and when to submerge ü¶õ

Leaders and teams struggle when confined to modes of 'exercising authority' or 'being flat.' ü§î

Teams ruled by overbearing leaders don't generate innovative, creative thinking.

Teams in 'flat' mode suffer from indecisive leadership, poor coordination, and ineffective execution.

Think of the hippopotamus: it knows when to emerge and exert dominance, and when to recede, leaving only its eyes visible. üí°

üåü Meetings offer a prime opportunity for leaders to shift power modes. How?

Ensure a psychologically safe environment for people to speak up.

Revisit our mindset: sharing power does not diminish our authority.

Conduct self and team analysis: assess personal habits and the team's norms.

Inform everyone when to engage in divergent thinking and when to shift to convergent thinking.

Set clear expectations: signal the working modes before meetings. Define shifts and use rituals to mark transitions.

Use effective body language. Nonverbal behavior can reinforce or undermine your message. Read the room and know when to shift from command and control to empowerment.

Leave, or avoid entering, the room. If everyone waits for your opinion, authority alone can squelch debate and create awkward silences. Retake charge to end the discussion, make a decision, and act.

data.text:
Beware the arrival fallacy: it's not about reaching; it's about being.

I will be happy when I finally get there. Right? ‚úîÔ∏è Wrong ‚ùå 

"Arrival fallacy is this illusion that once we make it, once we attain our goal or reach our destination, we will reach lasting happiness," said Tal Ben-Shahar, the Harvard positive psychology expert who coined the term. 

Achieving a goal will not magically make us happier when we graduate, get promoted, or win a competition.
¬†
‚û°Ô∏è We tend to be pretty good at knowing what will make us happy and unhappy, but we're not very good at predicting the intensity and the duration of the effect of events. That can leave us feeling let down after the fact.
¬†
‚û°Ô∏è On the other hand, the No. 1 predictor of happiness is the quality time spent with people we care about and who care about us. In other words, relationships.
¬†
‚û°Ô∏è To be clear, acknowledging the power of the arrival fallacy does not mean we should settle for a life of mediocrity. We need to have goals. We need to think about the future.
¬†
‚û°Ô∏è Since we are a "future-oriented" species, purpose and meaning can generate satisfaction, which is part of the happiness equation. So, the advice is to set multiple concurrent goals in and out of work life.

data.text:
Breaking stereotypes: why introverts can also make great leaders üôå

Can introverts be leaders? According to Andres Raya Donet, the answer is a resounding "yes" ‚ú®

Carl Jung says introverted individuals draw strength and energy from themselves and not from the outside.

They are reflective and calm, enjoy being in small groups, think deeply before deciding, and learn from observation.

Introverted individuals make up about half of the world's population. However, 96% of senior executives prefer to define themselves as extroverts because of prejudice. 

ü§ê Disclaimer: it is essential to avoid stereotypes. There is no better or worse profile; everyone can use their qualities to best deal with each context. And probably, we are not 100% extroverts or introverts.

‚úÖ Some of the strengths of introverted leaders:

They are more prone to humility.

They are excellent problem solvers.

They focus on actions rather than words.

They know how to generate enthusiasm and loyalty.

They are excellent mentors, as they strive to improve constantly.

They influence people by paying them attention and consideration.

They do not seek to dominate or feel threatened by proactive colleagues.

They will likely leave their ego in the background, even in high-stress situations.

‚úÖ Challenges introverted leaders face. In her book 'The Introverted Leader', Jennifer Kahnweiler talks about the "four P process," 

Preparation: working on doing things in the way that best suits personal character. 

Presence: always focus on the situation we have in front of us without wandering

Push: learning to get out of the comfort zone, assuming, from time to time, some risk.

Practice: take advantage of opportunities to act effectively without renouncing one's personality.

data.text:
Here is an embarassing lesson I learned from someone who signed up for one of my workshops üôà

Last week, I made a communication mistake so bad that for a moment I was tempted to hide under a rock.

But since I teach virtual communication, I thought I should walk my talk about learning from feedback üòâ

Here‚Äôs what happened:

Someone signed up for my virtual communication workshop and answered the pre-session question ‚Äúwhat is your biggest challenge‚Äù with "I don't know."

My immediate thought? "Oh great, another curious browser who'll take up a spot, and in the end be a no-show and mess up the group dynamic."

So I just ‚Äújumped the gun‚Äù and asked them to leave the spot for someone else.

Here's the thing: I was protecting something real. After hosting many workshops, I've experienced that "just curious" often means "won't engage meaningfully" or worse won't show up.

These sessions depend on preparation and participation, and it‚Äôs essential that people are committed and participate. The mood of the session also depends on the participants, and we co-create it.

But my frustration made me defensive instead of curious.

The feedback the person gave me: "Running people off is wrong and unprofessional. Better to ask instead of assume."

Ouch. ü§ï

What I should have asked:

"What made you curious about this topic?"
"What would make this workshop valuable for your time?"
"What's your situation and what makes you think this is relevant for you?"

The lesson: past patterns can cloud our judgment.

Yes, disengaged participants and no-shows are a real challenge for interactive workshops. But my job as a communicator is precisely to explore curiosity, not shut it down.

Maybe the people who say 'I don't know' are exactly the ones who need to be there most.

Have you ever let past frustrations influence how you handle present situations? What communication mistakes have taught you the most?

data.text:
Do we tend to focus on the negative details? üß†
¬†
Mental filtering is a cognitive distortion that leads us to magnify the negative details of a situation while filtering out the positive ones. ‚öñÔ∏è
¬†
Also known as selective abstraction, this bias of dwelling on our shortcomings could lead us to focus on one negative comment while disregarding or disbelieving the other ten positive comments.
¬†
So, how to manage mental filtering?
¬†
‚û°Ô∏è Recognise when mental filtering occurs. If our glass tends to be half-empty, we may explore our feelings further by journaling, which can also help us recognize the positives.¬†
¬†
‚û°Ô∏è Conduct a cost-benefit analysis. It can be used to support us in challenging the patterns of thinking that have led us to focus on the negative elements of a situation.
¬†
‚û°Ô∏è Ask for objective opinions. Asking our friends or colleagues for an objective opinion on our performance or achievements is a good way to gauge our ability or progress.¬†
¬†

Do we know how to ask good questions?
¬†
According to an article by John Coleman, asking better questions is the key to critical thinking. Here are a few ways to enhance your ability:
¬†
‚û°Ô∏è Hold your hypotheses loosely. Be willing to review your assumptions.
¬†
‚û°Ô∏è Listen more than you talk. Active listening is understanding what another person is saying while being engaged and interested.
¬†
‚û°Ô∏è Leave your queries open-ended. Avoid asking yes-or-no questions. Rather ‚Äúhow‚Äù, ‚Äúwhat‚Äù...
¬†
‚û°Ô∏è Consider the counterintuitive. Fight against groupthink, propose a counterintuitive question, one that challenges the group‚Äôs conventional thinking
¬†
‚û°Ô∏è Stew in a problem. Don‚Äôt jump the gun. Wait and reflect a bit.
¬†
‚û°Ô∏è Ask the hard follow-up questions. Do not accept easy answers, ask the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù.
¬†

data.text:
How many times do we say, "I'm not sure" .. "I made a mistake" .. or "I don't know" ? üòá

Being humble is a very effective way to earn trust and one of the keys to success in the future, according to Rachel Botsman in this classic Nordic Business Forum article.

Rachel sees trust as a force that helps us navigate uncertainty. 

‚û°Ô∏è Who do we trust?

When we reflect on who, what, and why we trust, we will also think more clearly about why people place trust in us.

‚û°Ô∏è Why is trust important?

Anytime we ask someone to do something new or do something differently, we ask them to make a trust leap.

How we look at trust leaps depends on our environment and our relationship to risk. 

‚û°Ô∏è Does transparency equal more trust?

Rachel believes there is a mistaken belief that transparency is the antidote to all our trust issues. 

When we demand complete visibility of our teams' actions, it creates a lack of trust. When we let go of control, we foster more trust.

‚û°Ô∏è How do we know if someone is trustworthy? Capability + character

Capability refers to how someone does things and is demonstrated in two key traits: competence + reliability.

Character refers to why you do things and is demonstrated in two key traits: empathy + integrity.

‚û°Ô∏è How do we earn trust?

The most powerful way to earn trust is ‚Ä¶ 'I don't know.' ‚ú®

Humility is the secret to earning trust. If we admit we don't know when we don't have answers, people will have more confidence when we offer decisions and direction.
